variant.question: For the formation of mountain waves, the wind above the level of the ridge should:

options.text: increase with little change in direction.
decrease or even reverse direction.
increase and then reverse in direction.
increase initially, then decrease.

variant.question: The conditions most favourable to the formation of mountain waves are...

options.text: wind direction approximately at right angles to the mountain range - wind speed 30 kt and steadily increasing with height - an inversion just above the crest level with less stable air above and below.
wind speed less than 15 kt and wind direction at right angles to mountains - intense radiation cooling at night, particularly at the higher levels.
wind direction parallel to the mountain range - wind speed increasing with height - extensive isothermal layer between mountain crests and the tropopause.
wind direction parallel to the general alignment of the mountain range - wind speed increasing with height - intense surface heating.

variant.question: At the top of standing waves, in mountainous regions, the cloud most likely to be encountered is

options.text: Altocumulus Lenticularis.
Cirrus.
Cumulus Mediocris.
Cirrostratus.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements are conditions that must be in place in order for mountain waves to form?
1. The wind blows within 30° of a right angle to the mountain range.
2. The wind speed abeam the top of the mountain exceeds 20 kt.
3. The wind speed decreases with altitude but the direction remains fairly constant.
4. The atmosphere is unstable on the windward side of the mountain top..

options.text: 1 and 2
3 and 4
2 and 4
1 and 3

variant.question: A mountain wave situation occurs without the formation of mountain wave clouds. What is the reason why the clouds have not formed?

options.text: the air is too dry.
the air mass is stable.
the winds are too strong.
presence of too strong turbulence.

variant.question: Up to which flight level could the effects of mountain waves be expected to be encountered?

options.text: FL600
FL450
FL300
FL150

variant.question: What adverse effects may mountain waves have over the aircraft?

options.text: It can exceed the performance or structural capability of the aircraft.
It can also reduce the engine power and lead to an engine failure.
Light turbulence leading to wings’ bending.
Increases the risk of ICI.

variant.question: In addition to a stable layer of air over a substantial mountain range, the conditions most favourable to the development of standing waves are...

options.text: wind speed in excess of 20 kt at the surface and increasing with height and wind direction perpendicular to the general direction of the range.
significant moisture loss due to precipitation and rapid lowering of the tropopause in the area of the mountain range.
conditional instability and constant wind speed from a direction parallel to the mountain range.
steep dry adiabatic lapse rate and wind speed increasing and changing direction rapidly with an increase in height.

variant.question: In addition to a stable layer of air over a substantial mountain range, the conditions most favourable to the development of standing waves are..

options.text: wind speed in excess of 20 kt at the surface and increasing with height and wind direction perpendicular to the general direction of the range.
conditional instability and constant wind speed from a direction parallel to the mountain range.
significant moisture loss due to precipitation and rapid lowering of the tropopause in the area of the mountain range.
steep dry adiabatic lapse rate and wind speed increasing and changing direction rapidly with an increase in height.

variant.question: A mountain range is aligned in a North - South direction. Select the conditions from the table below that could give rise to standing waves. Wind values given for 2 000 ft, 5 000 ft and 10 000 ft:
Mountain waves should be expected:

options.text: on the downwind side of the mountain range.
directly over the mountain chain.
on the upwind side of the mountain chain.
when instability is high.

variant.question: Mountain-wave airflow is commonly characterised by the fact that it..

options.text: has an oscillating motion on the lee side of the mountain range.
turns backwards and changes direction at the mountain top.
bypasses the mountain on each side.
first veers then backs when passing the mountain range.

variant.question: At the top of mountain waves, the cloud most likely to be encountered is...

options.text: altocumulus lenticularis.
cirrostratus.
cirrus.
cumulus mediocris.

variant.question: Name the most important conditions for the formation of significant lee waves within a mountain range.

options.text: A strong large-scale wind increase up to high levels and blowing approximately perpendicular towards the mountain range under a stable thermal stratification.
A strong heating of the air on the windward side, contrasting with strong cooling on the leeward side of the mountain range.
Lee waves form when strong winds blow parallel to the mountain range and split up into two branches. The wind shear across the crest causes lee waves.
Warm moist air arrives under an unstable thermal stratification on the windward side. Lee waves develop in the unstable stratification on the leeward side.

variant.question: Which of the following conditions are most favorable to the formation of mountain waves?

options.text: Stable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Either stable or unstable air at mountain top and a wind of at least 30 knots blowing parallel to the mountain ridge.
Moist unstable air at mountain top and wind of less than 5 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Unstable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.

variant.question: Which of the following conditions are most favorable to the formation of mountain waves?

options.text: Stable air, wind speed > 20 kts blowing across the ridge.
Unstable air, wind speed > 20 kts blowing across the ridge.
Stable air, wind speed > 30 kts blowing parallel to the ridge.
Unstable moist air, wind speed < 5 kts blowing across the ridge.

variant.question: Which of the following conditions are most favourable to the formation of mountain waves?

options.text: Stable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Either stable or unstable air at mountain top and a wind of at least 30 knots blowing parallel to the mountain ridge.
Moist unstable air at mountain top and wind of less than 5 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Unstable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.

variant.question: Which of the following conditions are most favourable to the formation of mountain waves?

options.text: Stable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge
Moist unstable air at mountain top and wind of less than 5 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Either stable or unstable air at mountain top and a wind of at least 30 knots blowing parallel to the mountain ridge.
Unstable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.

variant.question: Which of the following conditions are most favourable to the formation of mountain waves?

options.text:
Stable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least
20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.

Unstable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least
20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.

Either stable or unstable air at mountain top and a wind
of at least 30 knots blowing parallel to the mountain
ridge.

Moist unstable air at mountain top and wind of less than
5 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.

variant.question: Pilots should expect the occurrence of mountain waves up to...
Up to what level can you expect mountain waves?

options.text: FL600
FL100
FL250
FL350

variant.question: Conditions most favorable for the formation of mountain waves are:

options.text: Little change in wind direction with height, wind speeds increasing upwards through the troposphere, wind blowing within 30° of the perpendicular to the ridge, wind speed at the crest above 15 kt for small mountains and above 30 kt for large mountains.

Approximately a 90° change in wind direction with height, wing speeds increasing upwards through the troposphere, wind blowing within 30° of the perpendicular to the ridge, wind speed at the crest above 15 kt for small mountains and above 30 kt for large mountains.

Approximately a 90° change in wind direction with height, wind blowing within 30° of the perpendicular to the ridge, wind speed at the crest above 15 kt for small mountains and above 30 kt for large mountains.

Little change in wind direction with height, wind speeds increasing upwards through the troposphere, wind blowing within 90° of the perpendicular to the ridge, wind speed at the crest above 15 kt for small mountains and above 30 kt for large mountains.

variant.question: Which is correct regarding the propagation of mountain wave effects from low to high level?

options.text: When winds from a consistent direction, approximately perpendicular to a mountain range or high plateau, increase in speed with height within a deep, stable layer, mountain waves and their effects can extend from low to high level.

The presence of a jet stream passing over a mountain range tends to reinforce a mountain wave system that has developed at lower levels. This reinforcement provides the optimum conditions for the mountain waves to extend up to the level of the jet stream.

A strong westerly airflow that increases in speed with height, when combined with a deep, unstable layer in the vicinity of a mountain range, can often result in the wave motion, and its associated turbulence, extending from low through to high level.

A deep, stable layer combined with a consistent, strong, westerly flow at low level over a mountain range can result in a mountain wave system developing up to high level, when the decrease in air density with height is matched by a similar decrease in wind speed with height.

variant.question: A 10 000 ft high mountain range aligned in a North - South direction is producing marked mountain waves. For the formation of severe mountain waves, the air at the level of the ridge and the first few thousand feet above the ridge was:

options.text: stable with less stable layers above and below.
conditionally stable.
unstable with stable air above and below.
unstable.

variant.question: How far and how high up can mountain waves reach originating from the Rocky Mountains (USA)?

options.text: Up to the tropopause and 600 NM downwind.
By the dimensions of the affecting mountain.
Up to 36000 ft and approximately 300 NM downwind.
Up to the tropopause and horizontally as long as there’re mountains.

variant.question: How far and how high up can mountain waves reach originating from the Rocky Mountains (USA)?

options.text: Up to the tropopause and 600 NM downwind.
Up to 36 000 ft and approximately 300 NM downwind.
Up to the tropopause and horizontally as long as there’re mountains.
By the dimensions of the affecting mountain.

variant.question: A mountain wave situation occurs without the formation of mountain wave clouds. No clouds are formed because:

options.text: The air is too dry.
The airmass is stable.
The turbulence is too strong.
The winds are too strong.

variant.question: Which of the following is correct regarding mountain waves?

options.text: The airflow in a mountain-wave system is often smooth but vertical currents can be strong enough to exceed the performance capability of an aircraft.
Mountain waves tend to occur at low level, where the wave motion is severely weakened by the terrain and therefore the wave flow is NOT likely to be a hazard to aircraft.
For an aircraft entering in a mountain-wave system, the most likely hazard in the wave flow is severe turbulence in the area upwind of the mountain range.
In a mountain-wave system at medium to high level the smooth outline of any associated cloud indicates that turbulence and strong vertical currents are NOT likely to be present.

variant.question:
Which of these statements about mountain waves are correct or incorrect?

1. For the development of strong down- and up-drafts in mountain waves the atmosphere must be unstable.2. If a rotor occurs in a mountain wave it is always visible.

options.text: 1 and 2 are not correct.
1 is not correct, 2 is correct.
1 and 2 are correct.
1 is correct, 2 is not correct.

variant.question: Mention 3 types of weather phenomena associated with mountain waves

options.text: rotor, cap and lenticular clouds.
fog, lenticular and medium height clouds.
turbulence, advection and convection clouds.
low clouds, downdraughts and thunderstorms.

variant.question: Which of the following clouds is a typical indication for mountain waves?

options.text: altocumulus lenticularis
cumulonimbus
low stratus
cumulus mediocris

variant.question: What is likely when mountain waves are observed?

options.text: Strong wind and turbulence in the mountains.
Convective clouds.
Unstable air.
Rain on the leeward side of the mountain.

variant.question: Concerning an environment where mountain wave activity is present

options.text: When flying upwind, the aircraft is liable to be at its maximum height, when over high ground.
Upwind flight may not be safe, as height variations are usually out of phase with the waves.
Downwind flight is safer as height variations are out of phase with the waves.
Downwind flight may not be safe, as height variations are out of phase with the waves.

variant.question: Which of the following options correctly describes the propagation of mountain wave effects?

options.text: Mountain wave effects can propagate from low to high level.
Mountain wave effects are confined to the altitude of the standing wave.
The propagation of mountain wave effects is restricted to the windward side.
Mountain wave effects can propagate from the leeward side to windward side of mountain ranges.

variant.question: In a mountainous area, the most hazardous flying conditions associated with standing waves are likely to be experienced:

options.text: in the vicinity of the "roll" cloud or rotor zone beneath the first wave on the leeward side.
just above the lenticular cloud on the windward side.
on the windward side of the mountain just above the "cap" cloud.
between the troughs of the waves particularly 30 NM to 50 NM downwind and close to the tropopause.

variant.question: A 10 000 ft high mountain range aligned in a North - South direction is producing marked mountain waves. The greatest potential danger exists for an aircraft flying:

options.text: towards the ridge from the lee side at FL140.
above the line of clouds parallel to the ridge at FL250.
on the windward side of the ridge.
at FL350 over and parallel to the ridge.

variant.question: Possible turbulence caused by mountain wave activity should be anticipated in the following conditions:

options.text: stable air with wind speeds 25 kts or greater, blowing across a mountain ridge.
unstable air with wind speeds 25 kts or greater, blowing down a mountain valley.
unstable air with wind speeds 20 kts or greater, blowing across a mountain ridge.
stable air with wind speeds 25 kts or greater, blowing parallel to a mountain peak.
